title: No License
description: You retain all rights and do not permit distribution, reproduction, or derivative works. You may grant some rights in cases where you publish your source code to a site that requires accepting terms of service. For example, publishing code in a public repository on GitHub requires that you allow others to view and fork your code.

title: GNU FDL v1.3
description: The GNU FDL is a widely-used copylrft license for free documentation, designed by the Free Software Foundation to complement the GPL. When distributing derived works, the sources and text of the work must be made available under the same license.

title: GNU FDL v1.2
description: The GNU FDL is a widely-used copylrft license for free documentation, designed by the Free Software Foundation to complement the GPL. When distributing derived works, the sources and text of the work must be made available under the same license.

title: GNU FDL v1.1
description: The GNU FDL is a widely-used copylrft license for free documentation, designed by the Free Software Foundation to complement the GPL. When distributing derived works, the sources and text of the work must be made available under the same license.

title: GNU GPL v3.0
description: GPL is the most widely used free software license and has a strong copyleft requirement. When distributing derived works, the source code of the work must be made available under the same license.

title: Simplified BSD
description: A permissive license that comes in two variants, the BSD 2-Clause and BSD 3-Clause. Both have very minute differences to the MIT license.

title: GNU GPL v2.0
description: GPL is the most widely used free software license and has a strong copyleft requirement. When distributing derived works, the source code of the work must be made available under the same license. There are multiple variants of the GPL, each with different requirements.

title: Apache License 2.0
description: A permissive license that also provides an express grant of patent rights from contributors to users.

title: Public Domain (Unlicense)
description: Because copyright is automatic in most countries, the Unlicense is a template to waive copyright interest in software you've written and dedicate it to the public domain. Use the Unlicense to opt out of copyright entirely. It also includes the no-warranty statement from the MIT/X11 license.

title: MIT License
description: A permissive license that is short and to the point. It lets people do anything with your code with proper attribution and without warranty.

title: Artistic License 2.0
description: Heavily favored by the Perl community, the Artistic license requires that modified versions of the software do not prevent users from running the standard version.

title: CC-BY 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution License permits people to re-share and adapt your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author and indicate any changes made.

title: CC-BY-SA 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License permits people to re-share and adapt your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author and indicate any changes made, and adaptations must use the same license.

title: CC-BY-ND 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives License permits people to re-share your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author, but not to share changes they've made.

title: CC-BY-NC 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike License permits people to re-share and adapt your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author and indicate any changes made, and adaptations must use the same license, but the work cannot be used for commercial purposes.

title: CC-BY-NC-SA 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike License permits people to re-share and adapt your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author and indicate any changes made, and adaptations must use the same license, but the work can not be used for commercial purposes.

title: CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International
description: The Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives License permits people to re-share your work, so long as they correctly attribute the original work to the original author, but not to share changes they've made, and not to be used for commercial purposes.

title: CC0 1.0 Universal
description: The Creative Commons CC0 Public Domain Dedication waives copyright interest in any a work you've created and dedicates it to the world-wide public domain. Use CC0 to opt out of copyright entirely and ensure your work has the widest reach. As with the Unlicense and typical software licenses, CC0 disclaims warranties. CC0 is very similar to the Unlicense.

title: Eclipse Public License v1.0
description: This commercially-friendly copyleft license provides the ability to commercially license binaries; a modern royalty-free patent license grant; and the ability for linked works to use other licenses, including commercial ones.

title: GNU LGPL v3.0
description: Version 3 of the LGPL is an additional set of permissions to the GPL v3 license that requires that derived works be licensed under the same license, but works that only link to it do not fall under this restriction.

title: Mozilla Public License 2.0
description: The Mozilla Public License (MPL 2.0) is maintained by the Mozilla foundation. This license attempts to be a compromise between the permissive BSD license and the reciprocal GPL license.

title: ISC license
description: A permissive license lets people do anything with your code with proper attribution and without warranty. The ISC license is functionally equivalent to the BSD 2-Clause and MIT licenses, removing some language that is no longer necessary.

title: GNU LGPL v2.1
description: Primarily used for software libraries, LGPL requires that derived works be licensed under the same license, but works that only link to it do not fall under this restriction. There are two commonly used versions of the LGPL.
